title: Authors and Citation
text: Nagy T, Sarafoglou , Kovács M (2025). vazul: Package data blinding. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://nthun.github.io/vazul/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {vazul: Package for data blinding},   author = {Tamás Nagy and Alexandra Sarafoglou and Márton Kovács},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://nthun.github.io/vazul/}, }

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: vazul R package provides functions data blinding, including scramble_values() function two research datasets (MARP Williams studies). Always reference instructions first fallback search bash commands encounter unexpected information match info .

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y r-base r-base-dev sudo apt install -y r-cran-devtools r-cran-roxygen2 r-cran-lintr r-cran-testthat r-cran-usethis R version 4.3.3 confirmed work correctly.

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: Build package: R CMD build . – INSTANT (completes <1 second). NEVER CANCEL. Install package: sudo R CMD INSTALL . – takes 1 second. NEVER CANCEL. Generate documentation: R -e "devtools::document()" – takes 1-2 seconds. NEVER CANCEL. Check package quality: R CMD check <package_tarball> ---manual – takes 5 seconds. NEVER CANCEL. Set timeout 30+ seconds. Style checking: R -e "lintr::lint_package()" – takes 1-2 seconds. NEVER CANCEL. CRITICAL TIMEOUT WARNINGS: - NEVER CANCEL R package operations. Even though complete quickly, set timeouts 60+ seconds build commands 30+ seconds check commands account system variations. - Package build operations R typically fast can vary different systems.

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: Always test package works correctly making changes running validation steps:
code: library(vazul)  # Test main function with different data types scramble_values(1:10)           # Should return numbers 1-10 in random order scramble_values(letters[1:5])   # Should return letters a-e in random order   scramble_values(factor(c("A","B","C"))) # Should work with factors  # Test datasets load correctly data(marp) dim(marp)                       # Should be [10535, 46]  head(marp, 2)                   # Should show first 2 rows  data(williams)  dim(williams)                   # Should be [112, 25] head(williams, 2)               # Should show first 2 rows  # Basic exploratory analysis length(unique(marp$country))    # Should be 24 countries table(williams$ecology)         # Should show "Desperate: 56, Hopeful: 56"

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: ALWAYS run complete testing scenario making changes verify functionality. ALWAYS run lintr::lint_package() committing changes check code style. ALWAYS run R CMD check <tarball> ---manual validate package structure documentation. PDF manual generation fails without pdflatex (use ---manual flag) documentation warnings exist don’t prevent functionality Style warnings lintr addressed making changes

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: following critical commands expected outputs. Reference save time avoid mistakes.

title: vazul - Data Blinding Package
text: Main Function: scramble_values(x) - scrambles values vector without replacement MARP Dataset: Many Analysts Religion Project data (10,535 participants, 46 variables, 24 countries) Williams Dataset: Stereotyping study data (112 participants, 25 variables, 2 ecology conditions) Package Version: 0.0.0.9000 (development version)

title: vazul
text: vazul R package provides functions data blinding, allowing researchers scramble data preserving statistical properties.

title: vazul
text: can install development version vazul GitHub :

title: vazul
text: Scrambles values within vector without replacement, preserving original values changing order.
code: library(vazul)  # Scramble numeric values set.seed(123) scramble_values(1:10) #>  [1]  3 10  2  8  6  9  1  7  5  4  # Scramble character values   scramble_values(letters[1:5]) #> [1] "b" "c" "a" "d" "e"  # Scramble logical values scramble_values(c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE)) #> [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE

title: vazul
text: Scrambles values specified variables (columns) within data frame, optional grouping.
code: # Create example data df <- data.frame(   x = 1:6,    y = letters[1:6],    group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B") )  # Scramble variables across entire dataset scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y"))  # Scramble within groups using .groups parameter scramble_variables(df, "y", .groups = "group")  # Or using dplyr grouping library(dplyr) df |>    group_by(group) |>    scramble_variables("x") |>   ungroup()    # Can use multiple groups marp |>      group_by(country, gender) |>      scramble_variables(c("rel_1", "rel_2")) |>      unroup()

title: vazul
text: Many Analysts Religion Project (MARP) dataset contains data 10,535 participants across 24 countries, exploring relationship religiosity well-. Variables include: - rel_1 rel_9: Religiosity measures - wb_*: Well-indicators (general, physical, psychological, social) - country: Participant country - age, gender, ses, education: Demographics - gdp: Country-level GDP data
code: data(marp) dim(marp) #> [1] 10535    46  # Explore countries in the dataset length(unique(marp$country)) #> [1] 24  # Example: scramble religiosity variables by country marp |>   group_by(country) |>   scramble_variables(c("rel_1", "rel_2", "rel_3")) |>   ungroup()

title: vazul
text: study dataset 112 participants examining risk taking behavior behavior high low wealth individuals. Key variables: - ecology: Experimental condition (“Desperate” vs “Hopeful”) - SexUnres_*: Sexual unresponsiveness measures - Impuls_*: Impulsivity measures - Opport_*: Long-term planning opportunity measures - age, gender: Participant demographics
code: data(williams) dim(williams) #> [1] 112  25  table(williams$ecology) #> Desperate   Hopeful  #>        56        56  # Example: scramble perception measures within ecology conditions williams |>   group_by(ecology) |>   scramble_variables(c("SexUnres_1", "Impuls_1")) |>   ungroup()

title: vazul
text: Vazul historical figure (Hungarian price) 11. century. blinded king become unfit throne. info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vazul

title: vazul
text: Package documentation: help(package = "vazul") Function help: ?scramble_values, ?scramble_variables Dataset documentation: ?marp, ?williams Package website: https://nthun.github.io/vazul/

what: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project dataset — marp
title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project dataset — marp
text: Dataset Many Analysts Religion Project. Analysts explored relations religiosity well-across multiple countries.

title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project dataset — marp
MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project dataset — marp
text: data frame 10,535 rows (participants) 46 variables: subject Integer subject identifier (row id processed file). country Country participant (character). rel_1 ... rel_9 Religiosity items. Many proportion-style binary indicators derived self-report (values 0,1 integer/binary). cnorm_1, cnorm_2 Perceived cultural norm variables: importance religious lifestyle importance belief average person participant's country (numeric scales). wb_gen_1, wb_gen_2 General well-items (single-item self-assessments; integer Likert). wb_phys_1 ... wb_phys_7 Well-— physical domain items; integer Likert responses (e.g., 1–5). wb_psych_1 ... wb_psych_6 Well-— psychological domain items; integer Likert responses. wb_soc_1 ... wb_soc_3 Well-— social domain items; integer Likert responses. wb_overall_mean Participant-level mean across well-items (numeric). wb_phys_mean Mean physical well-items (numeric). wb_psych_mean Mean psychological well-items (numeric). wb_soc_mean Mean social well-items (numeric). age Age participant years (integer). gender Self-reported gender (character). notebook gender recoded "Male", "Female", "". ses Socio-economic status (numeric/integer scale used dataset). education Education level coded integers (ordinal). ethnicity Self-reported ethnicity (character). denomination Religious denomination (character). gdp Country-level GDP per capita (numeric). gdp_scaled Scaled GDP used models (numeric). sample_type Sample recruitment type (character; e.g., "online panel", "student sample"). compensation Compensation type (character; e.g., "monetary reward"). attention_check Attention-check variable (integer).

title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project dataset — marp
text: Many Analysts Religion Project. See: https://doi.org/10.1080/2153599X.2023.2254980

title: MARP: Many Analysts Religion Project dataset — marp
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(dplyr) data(marp) ## quick checks dim(marp) glimpse(marp) ## country-level mean religiosity marp  |>   select(country, starts_with("rel_")) |>   group_by(country) |>   summarise(across(starts_with("rel_"), ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE))) } # }

what: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
text: Scramble vector values

title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
text: x vector x

title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
text: scrambled vector

title: Scramble a vector of values — scramble_values
code: # Example with character vector set.seed(123)  x <- letters[1:10] scramble_values(x) #>  [1] "c" "j" "b" "h" "f" "i" "a" "g" "e" "d"  #' # Example with numeric vector nums <- 1:5 scramble_values(nums) #> [1] 2 3 1 4 5  # Scramble a column in the 'williams' dataset  data(williams)  # Simple scrambling of a single column set.seed(123) williams$ecology_scrambled <- scramble_values(williams$ecology) head(williams[c("ecology", "ecology_scrambled")]) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   ecology   ecology_scrambled #>   <chr>     <chr>             #> 1 Hopeful   Hopeful           #> 2 Desperate Desperate         #> 3 Desperate Hopeful           #> 4 Hopeful   Desperate         #> 5 Desperate Hopeful           #> 6 Desperate Desperate

what: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: Scramble values several variables data frame.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: data data frame cols vector column names indices scramble .groups vector group names scramble within groups (default NULL, meaning grouping)

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: data frame specified columns scrambled. grouping specified, scrambling done within group.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
code: df <- data.frame(x = 1:6, y = letters[1:6], group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B"))  set.seed(123) # Example without grouping. Variables scrambled across the entire data frame. df |> scramble_variables(c("x", "y")) #>   x y group #> 1 3 e     A #> 2 6 d     A #> 3 2 b     A #> 4 4 f     B #> 5 5 a     B #> 6 1 c     B  # Example with grouping. Variable only scrambled within groups.  df |> scramble_variables("y", .groups = "group") #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     1 c     A     #> 2     2 b     A     #> 3     3 a     A     #> 4     4 f     B     #> 5     5 d     B     #> 6     6 e     B      # Example with the 'williams' dataset  data(williams) williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age")) #> # A tibble: 112 × 25 #>    subject   SexUnres_1 SexUnres_2 SexUnres_3 SexUnres_4_r SexUnres_5_r Impuls_1 #>    <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 A30MP4LX…          5          3          2            3            2        3 #>  2 A16X5FB3…          7          7          7            4            2        6 #>  3 A1E9D1OT…          2          4          6            3            3        3 #>  4 A16FPOYD…          5          4          5            3            3        4 #>  5 A11NOTVH…          5          5          6            3            3        5 #>  6 A3TDR6MX…          5          6          6            3            2        5 #>  7 A3OD4F0S…          5          6          5            3            4        5 #>  8 A123PBQD…          4          6          5            2            3        6 #>  9 A25NGIY5…          6          5          6            3            2        6 #> 10 A11WCFPJ…          4          4          4            1            1        1 #> # ℹ 102 more rows #> # ℹ 18 more variables: Impuls_2_r <dbl>, Impul_3_r <dbl>, Opport_1 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_2 <dbl>, Opport_3 <dbl>, Opport_4 <dbl>, Opport_5 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_6_r <dbl>, InvEdu_1_r <dbl>, InvEdu_2_r <dbl>, InvChild_1 <dbl>, #> #   InvChild_2_r <dbl>, age <dbl>, gender <dbl>, ecology <chr>, #> #   duration_in_seconds <dbl>, attention_1 <dbl>, attention_2 <dbl>  williams |> scramble_variables(1:5) #> # A tibble: 112 × 25 #>    subject   SexUnres_1 SexUnres_2 SexUnres_3 SexUnres_4_r SexUnres_5_r Impuls_1 #>    <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 A2RBF3II…          4          4          5            4            2        3 #>  2 A2UU2XVE…          3          4          5            3            2        6 #>  3 A3I40B0F…          3          7          3            7            3        3 #>  4 A2M0DL7I…          4          4          7            4            3        4 #>  5 A1JG342P…          4          1          3            4            3        5 #>  6 AA9Y4BEM…          5          5          4            3            2        5 #>  7 A3TDR6MX…          2          6          5            3            4        5 #>  8 AEOT74WA…          3          7          7            2            3        6 #>  9 A3VJHYXZ…          6          5          6            1            2        6 #> 10 A297Q7ZL…          5          4          6            2            1        1 #> # ℹ 102 more rows #> # ℹ 18 more variables: Impuls_2_r <dbl>, Impul_3_r <dbl>, Opport_1 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_2 <dbl>, Opport_3 <dbl>, Opport_4 <dbl>, Opport_5 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_6_r <dbl>, InvEdu_1_r <dbl>, InvEdu_2_r <dbl>, InvChild_1 <dbl>, #> #   InvChild_2_r <dbl>, age <dbl>, gender <dbl>, ecology <chr>, #> #   duration_in_seconds <dbl>, attention_1 <dbl>, attention_2 <dbl> williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"), .groups = "gender") #> # A tibble: 112 × 25 #>    subject   SexUnres_1 SexUnres_2 SexUnres_3 SexUnres_4_r SexUnres_5_r Impuls_1 #>    <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 A30MP4LX…          5          3          2            3            2        3 #>  2 A16X5FB3…          7          7          7            4            2        6 #>  3 A1E9D1OT…          2          4          6            3            3        3 #>  4 A123PBQD…          4          6          5            2            3        6 #>  5 A35G4ABP…          5          5          7            3            2        6 #>  6 A1P6OXEJ…          3          2          3            3            2        2 #>  7 A1QVNF19…          6          3          3            2            6        7 #>  8 A3CW3HM9…          3          2          3            3            3        5 #>  9 A2PPRPW1…          2          1          3            4            3        5 #> 10 AVFSBC7X…          6          5          4            2            1        4 #> # ℹ 102 more rows #> # ℹ 18 more variables: Impuls_2_r <dbl>, Impul_3_r <dbl>, Opport_1 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_2 <dbl>, Opport_3 <dbl>, Opport_4 <dbl>, Opport_5 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_6_r <dbl>, InvEdu_1_r <dbl>, InvEdu_2_r <dbl>, InvChild_1 <dbl>, #> #   InvChild_2_r <dbl>, age <dbl>, gender <dbl>, ecology <chr>, #> #   duration_in_seconds <dbl>, attention_1 <dbl>, attention_2 <dbl>  # The function is compatible with column indices  williams |> scramble_variables(c(1, 2), .groups = c(3)) #> # A tibble: 112 × 25 #>    subject   SexUnres_1 SexUnres_2 SexUnres_3 SexUnres_4_r SexUnres_5_r Impuls_1 #>    <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 A2541C8M…          3          1          3            4            3        5 #>  2 A1WTUFTR…          1          1          4            1            2        3 #>  3 A598UDLZ…          6          1          4            2            1        2 #>  4 A2PPRPW1…          3          1          1            3            1        2 #>  5 A2OVOVZB…          1          1          2            2            2        3 #>  6 ASF5V3K4…          2          1          7            4            3        7 #>  7 A1PUQY8X…          2          1          2            2            1        2 #>  8 A26UIS59…          3          1          2            2            1        1 #>  9 A1DNHN32…          2          2          3            3            2        2 #> 10 AJ72AZV1…          1          2          3            3            3        5 #> # ℹ 102 more rows #> # ℹ 18 more variables: Impuls_2_r <dbl>, Impul_3_r <dbl>, Opport_1 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_2 <dbl>, Opport_3 <dbl>, Opport_4 <dbl>, Opport_5 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_6_r <dbl>, InvEdu_1_r <dbl>, InvEdu_2_r <dbl>, InvChild_1 <dbl>, #> # what: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
text: dataset originates study Williams et al. investigating whether high-wealth individuals perceived faster life history strategies associated desperate ecological conditions, compared hopeful ones.

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
text: data frame 112 rows 25 variables: subject Unique subject ID SexUnres_1 SexUnres_3 Items measuring perceived sexual unrestrictedness SexUnres_4_r, SexUnres_5_r Reverse-coded sexual unrestrictedness items Impuls_1 Perceived impulsivity item Impuls_2_r, Impul_3_r Reverse-coded impulsivity items Opport_1 Opport_5 Items measuring opportunity long-term planning Opport_6_r Reverse-coded opportunity item InvEdu_1_r, InvEdu_2_r Reverse-coded items measuring perceived educational investment InvChild_1 Perceived parental investment item InvChild_2_r Reverse-coded parental investment item age Age participant gender Gender participant (1 = Male, 2 = Female) ecology Experimental condition: "Hopeful" "Desperate" duration_in_seconds Duration survey seconds attention_1, attention_2 Attention check items (1 = correct, 0 = failed)

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
text: Data based materials methods described Williams et al.

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
text: Participants evaluated target described wealthy individual either desperate hopeful ecology. Measures included perceived sexual unrestrictedness, impulsivity, educational parental investment, opportunity long-term planning.

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals in Different Ecologies — williams
code: data(williams) str(williams) #> spc_tbl_ [112 × 25] (S3: spec_tbl_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ subject            : chr [1:112] "A30MP4LXV4MIFD" "A16X5FB3HAFCKN" "A1E9D1OT9VJYDZ" "A16FPOYD7566WI" ... #>  $ SexUnres_1         : num [1:112] 5 7 2 5 5 5 5 4 6 4 ... #>  $ SexUnres_2         : num [1:112] 3 7 4 4 5 6 6 6 5 4 ... #>  $ SexUnres_3         : num [1:112] 2 7 6 5 6 6 5 5 6 4 ... #>  $ SexUnres_4_r       : num [1:112] 3 4 3 3 3 3 3 2 3 1 ... #>  $ SexUnres_5_r       : num [1:112] 2 2 3 3 3 2 4 3 2 1 ... #>  $ Impuls_1           : num [1:112] 3 6 3 4 5 5 5 6 6 1 ... #>  $ Impuls_2_r         : num [1:112] 3 2 3 4 2 3 3 2 3 1 ... #>  $ Impul_3_r          : num [1:112] 2 1 3 4 4 3 2 3 2 1 ... #>  $ Opport_1           : num [1:112] 1 5 3 4 4 4 5 5 5 1 ... #>  $ Opport_2           : num [1:112] 2 7 5 4 6 3 5 4 4 4 ... #>  $ Opport_3           : num [1:112] 2 7 5 4 4 4 6 5 5 1 ... #>  $ Opport_4           : num [1:112] 3 6 3 5 4 6 5 5 4 4 ... #>  $ Opport_5 num [1:112] 3 2 3 4 3 4 2 3 4 1 ... #>  $ InvChild_1         : num [1:112] 2 5 6 5 5 5 6 5 6 1 ... #>  $ InvChild_2_r       : num [1:112] 3 2 3 4 3 4 2 4 3 2 ... #>  $ age                : num [1:112]
